awd_titl_txt: AitF: Full: Algorithms and Probabilistic Semantics for Next-Generation Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
A common objective in many computer networks is to balance traffic across multiple paths in order to improve throughput, reduce congestion, and achieve higher utilization. Although there is an extensive theoretical literature on how best to route traffic through a capacitated network, most networks today rely on schemes that are easy to implement but do not always perform well in practice. This is due, in part, to the gap between the community of theory researchers who study advanced routing schemes and the community of systems researchers who design, build, and operate networks.

This project will advance the theory and practice of routing by developing oblivious and semi-oblivious routing algorithms that can be implemented on top of current hardware. The intellectual merit of this research lies in designing new programming languages based on probabilistic semantics that can be used to express and reason about these algorithms, and engineering implementations for these languages based on software-defined networking platforms. This project will have broad impact on society by producing tools that could help to make networks more reliable and efficient while simplifying network management.

por.por_cntn:
A common goal in many networks is to distribute load across multiple paths to achieve higher utilization, minimize congestion, and improve throughput. But although there is an extensive literature on how best to route traffic through a capacitated network, networks today often rely on simple schemes that are easy to implement but perform poorly in practice. Recent advances in the theory community have suggested promising alternatives, but these approaches have been rarely implemented and evaluated on real-world workloads. The overall goal of this project was to develop new programming languages that can be used to express and reason about probabilistic behaviors including advanced routing schemes based on randomization.

During the course of this project, we invented a new programming language called ProbNetKAT that can be used to express and reason about a wide variety of probabilistic behaviors. This is in contrast to earlier languages (e.g., Frenetic, Pyretic, NetKAT) and tools (e.g., Veriflow and Header Space Analysis), which were based on deterministic functions. Defining a semantics that captures the behaviors that arise in networks turned out to be surprisingly challenging due to a number of subtle issues (e.g., handling continuous distributions, and ensuring that the infinite sequences of distributions generated by programs with loops converge to a final value). We developed a compositional semantics for ProbNetKAT based on Markov kernels that conservatively extends the semantics NetKAT language. We invented syntactic techniques for approximating the distributions generated by programs using simple program transformations. We proved a general result in the area of probabilistic semantics, showing that the Kolmogorov extension theorem and the Doob martingale convergence theorem are two aspects of a common generalization. Finally, we used ProbNetKAT to encode a variety of routing algorithms including shortest-path routing, equal cost multi-path routing, Valiant load balancing, and oblivious routing.

In addition to our research work, we also engaged in educational and outreach efforts. We mentored an undergraduate student and a postdoctoral researcher, both of whom continue to pursue research. We also engaged with colleagues in industry, including an Internet service provider and a large content provider, to facilitate technology transfer.
